Graduates will learn to install, program, adjust, and maintain building automation systems. They will also collect data for use in real-time or archiving in a central server, work with building software platforms, and gain skills for "green" careers focused on energy efficiency and sustainability.

Industry Skills:
- Safety practices in the installation and troubleshooting of HVAC/R systems according to codes and standards of NEC, ASHRAE, OSHA, EPA, etc.
- Basic HVAC/R processes and operation of commercial HVAC/R systems.
- Control loops and control modes in digital, analog, and pneumatic commercial control systems.
- Reading blueprints and manufacturer’s technical instructions for installing or servicing sensors, controllers, actuators, and related relays and power supplies.
- General-purpose software and specific building automation software for monitoring and controlling HVAC/R and electrical systems.
- Various BAS controls and systems including DCS, PLC, PAC, and SCADA.
- Functions of network devices and protocols like a bridge, router, gateway, hub, firewall, twisted pair, Ethernet, TCP/IP, Zigbee, WiFi, BAS/IP, and BACnet.
- Emerging green technologies such as solar, wind, and hydronic, and their integration into building systems and residential applications.

After graduating from this program, one can work in various industries such as electronics companies, general contractors, communication and information systems companies, lighting suppliers and contractors, mechanical and electronic controller manufacturers, facilities management companies, autonomous vehicles and robotics companies, residential developers, etc.

The program consists of six semesters. In the first semester, students take courses like Circuit Analysis, Mechanical Engineering Design, Machining Fundamentals and Metrology, Occupational Health and Safety, Personal Finance, Mathematics for Engineering Technology 1, Communicating Across Contexts, etc.

In the third semester, students learn about Introduction to PLC Systems, Digital Electronics, Operations Management & Quality Control, Sensors and Instrumentation, Automation Software Development, Blueprint Reading for Buildings, and a General Education elective.

In the fourth semester, students take courses like Instrumentation 2, Internet of Things for Homes, Network Fundamentals, Advanced PLC Systems, Sustainable Energy Technologies, and Thermodynamics.

In the fifth semester, students study Applied Project 1, Building Science Fundamentals, Building Networks and Protocols, Alarm and Video Systems, Building Control Systems, and Fundamentals of HVAC/R Systems.
